Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research fellowship awarded to Andrew S. Marks is "Recursion theory and descriptive set theory." The host institution for the fellowship is California Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Alexander Kechris.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The post-doctoral research was carried out at the California Institute of Technology under the supervision of Alexander Kechris. Professor Kechris is a leading expert in the field of descriptive set theory, and there were also many opportunities to interact with logicians in the Los Angeles area, particularly at UCLA and UC Irvine. This made Caltech an excellent venue for postdoctoral training and scientific development.

The field of descriptive set theory gives a general setting for studying the difficulty of classification problems in mathematics. One aspect of the project was using this framework to study classification problems arising in computability theory. An important motivation for this work is that it is connected to old problems in computability theory such as Martin's conjecture on Turing-invariant functions, and sheds new light on them. This work led to a new approach to proving Martin's conjecture using rigidity for Borel cocycles of shift actions of free groups.

A second focus of the project was the study of combinatorial problems on Borel graphs. There are many instances in mathematics where not only would we like to know that a solution to some combinatorial problems exists, but we would like to know that it can be explicitly described. A key success of the project came from isolating problems of this kind from computability theory and then developing game-theoretic tools for solving them, as well as a host of other problems in Borel graph combinatorics. These new tools are described in the article "A determinacy approach to Borel combinatorics" which has been accepted by the Journal of the American Math Society.

The results of the project have been broadly disseminated in talks and journal articles. During the postdoctoral fellowship I have been involved with the Turing centenary research project and spoken at its annual workshops along with other investigators in a wide range of disciplines: the history of science, philosophy, computer science, computational biology, and mathematics. These workshops have been open to the public and have provided valuable opportunities to interact with other researchers who have a wide ranging set of interests in computability. I have also spoken at conferences in other areas of math such as ergodic theory and operator algebras where there have been connections to the work of the project. Finally, I have given lecture series at two summer schools in logic: one for undergraduates, and the other for graduate students. These lectures have introduced the basics of computability and descriptive set theory to these audiences, and given a window into topics of current research.
